Description: Describes how facts determined by observations or experiments lead to explanations, not opinions.
The goal of science is to answer questions about the natural world using the scientific method.
Defines a hypothesis as a reasonable explanation that must be testable and falsifiable.
Presents the steps of the scientific method and how they are used to test hypotheses.
Distinguishes between correlation, the mutual relationship between things, and causation, the effect on one thing of changes in another.
Illuminates the use of scientific method to test hypotheses using observations and experiments.
Describes a theory as an explanation supported by evidence with no major inconsistencies; defines law.

Level 3: Evolution, Plate Tectonics, and Climate Change
Description: Introduces three of the important theories in Earth Science: the theory of evolution, the theory of plate tectonics, and the theory of climate change due to human activities.
Discusses the main types of scientific models and illuminates their value and limitations.
Learn how the scientific community shares results and monitors scientific integrity.
Presents the branches of earth science including geology, oceanography, meteorology, climatology, environmental science, and astronomy.
Describes the importance of fieldwork in earth science for gathering data and also some of the important locations featured in this concepts collection.
Uniformitarianism states that what happens today also happened in the past with the same results.
Explains the purpose of using latitude, longitude, and direction as an expression of location on Earth.
Location on Earth is usually expressed using latitude and longitude; how GPS works.
How we express direction; how to use a compass.
Elevation is height above sea level; elevation data reveals the shape of landforms.
Explores types of maps and the information they show, including topographic, bathymetric, and geologic.
Explains the different types of map projections, as well as their individual distortions.
Using topographic and geologic maps.
Examines how oceanographers learn about the seafloor and water column.
Categorizes telescopes by the part of the electromagnetic spectrum they use and how they work.

Level 3: Study of Space by the Electromagnetic Spectrum
Description: Scientists use the electromagnetic spectrum to learn about objects in space.
Reveals how rockets propel objects into space, such as satellites and space stations.
Examines the particles that make up matter such as subatomic particles, atoms, and molecules.
Discusses types of chemical bonding including ionic, covalent, and hydrogen.
Clarifies how people know that Earth is round and how it is divided into hemispheres.
Describes that the magnetic field is like a bar magnet inside Earth and the properties of the field to flip.
Looks at Earth's rotation on its axis and how that leads to the day-night cycle.
Describes how Earth revolves around the Sun with the other seven planets of the solar system in an orbit that is slightly elliptical.
Coriolis is an effect of Earth's rotation that helps to determine the directions of air and water currents.
Shows how seasons are the result of Earth's axial tilt and describes solstices and equinoxes.
Presents the configuration of the Sun, Moon, and Earth that leads to solar and lunar eclipses.
Explains what happens when the Sun, Moon, and Earth lead to a solar eclipse.
Explains what happens when the Sun, Moon, and Earth lead to a lunar eclipse.
Describes lunar phases as phases of the Moon cause by Earth's shadow.
Discover how scientists learn about Earth's interior using seismic waves, meteorites, density, and the magnetic field.
Identifies the various layers of the Earth, including the crust, mantle, core, lithosphere, and asthenosphere.
Looks at Earth's rotation on its axis and how that leads to the day-night cycle.
The crust, mantle and core are defined by composition; the lithosphere and asthenosphere from mechanical properties.
Distinguishes between the two types of crust: thin, dense, mafic oceanic and thicker, less dense, felsic continental.
Presents fundamental information about the composition of Earth's mantle and how heat moves within and from it.
Summarizes what we know about the core's properties.
The lithosphere is made of the brittle crust and uppermost mantle and lies on the plastic asthenosphere.
Discusses the definition of a mineral as a naturally occurring, inorganic substance, with a definite composition and crystal form.
Explores the composition and properties of the mineral groups.
Elucidates the properties that allow us to identify minerals such as color, streak, luster, density, hardness, cleavage, fracture, and others.
Examines the way minerals form from magma and solutions such as salt water and geothermal water.
Minerals make up the three types of rocks: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.
Presents the three major rock types and the processes that lead to their formation in the rock cycle.
Presents igneous rocks, which form from magma, and the two types: dense, dark mafic and less dense, light felsic.
Describes the features of intrusive and extrusive igneous rocks that cool slowly and rapidly, respectively.
Presents the classifications of igneous rocks based on silica content.
Describes how sediments weather, erode, and are deposited in a sedimentary environment.
Describes how sediments become sedimentary rocks by compression, compaction, and cementation.
Explains that sedimentary rocks are classified by how they formed and by grain size.
Covers metamorphic rocks, which form from previous rocks exposed to heat and/or pressure.
Explains that metamorphic rocks are classified on the basis of texture (grain size, shape, orientation) and mineral composition.
Introduces energy, which can change forms but cannot be created nor destroyed.
Describes usable energy and energy efficiency, which are important to understanding the value of energy resources.
Presents energy use and conservation, which is less expensive than harnessing new energy sources.
Compares and contrasts renewable and nonrenewable energy resources, which is based on whether a resource can be replaced faster than it is used or not.
Fossil fuels are created when organisms are buried quickly and altered by intense heat and pressure.
Coal is a solid fossil fuel that forms from ancient swamps and is currently the source of most electricity.
Explains how petroleum forms, what it is used for, and the consequences its usage has for the environment.
Describes that natural gas forms like crude oil but at higher temperatures. The techniques for obtaining it may be environmentally damaging.
Reveals the presence of alternative sources of fossil fuels, like shale and tar sands, and their limitations.
Describes the energy that is harnessed in nuclear power plants and some of the costs and benefits.
Explains what solar energy is, how it is harnessed, and some of its benefits and costs.
Provides an overview of where hydroelectric power and some of its benefits and costs.
Explains how wind energy is harnessed and used, and some of its benefits and costs.
Presents the way geothermal energy is harnessed and some of its benefits and costs.
Describes biomass energy, its future, and some of its benefits and costs.
Identifies a few of the reneweable and nonrenewable resources used by our species.
Identifies some of the valuable minerals and metals, and how they are located, mined, and refined.
Compares and contrasts renewable and nonrenewable resources, which is based on whether a resource can be replaced faster than it is used or not.
Valuable minerals and metals may make up an ore deposit.
Valuable minerals and metals are located, mined, and refined.
Ore deposits are mined and refined to become useful materials.
Explores some of the factors that affect the cost of resources, such as availability, ease of extraction, and politics.
Presents ways to conserve natural resources and why conservation is important.
Illuminates Wegener's continental drift hypothesis and his supporting evidence including the distribution of fossils, rocks, structures, and the climate zones.

Level 3: Wegener and the Continental Drift Hypothesis
Description: Discusses how the lack of a plausible mechanism kept Wegener's colleagues from accepting his continental drift hypothesis.

Level 3: Magnetic Polarity Evidence for Continental Drift
Description: Discusses how the lack of a plausible mechanism kept Wegener's colleagues from accepting his continental drift hypothesis.
Describes features of the seafloor and how they are mapped by echo sounding.
Explains how magnetic polarity frozen into seafloor basalts reveals evidence for the creation of new seafloor at mid-ocean ridges.
Reveals how seafloor topography, magnetic polarity, and age are evidence for the sea floor spreading hypothesis.
The tectonic plates are slabs of lithosphere that are outlined by earthquake epicenters.
Explains how convection in the mantle moves the tectonic plates on Earth's surface.
Plate tectonics theory predicts the locations of earthquakes, volcanoes, mountain ranges, ore deposits, and other geological phenomena.

Level 3: Divergent Plate Boundaries in the Oceans
Description: Describes how the divergence of plates in the oceans leads to seafloor spreading.
Describes how the divergence of plates on a continent leads to continental rifting.
Looks at transform plate boundaries in which two plates slide past each other at a transform fault.
Covers ocean-ocean and ocean-continent convergent plate boundaries, including the creation of volcanic arcs and earthquakes.
Learn that subduction of the older, denser oceanic crust leads to the formation of a volcanic island arc and accompanying earthquakes.
Explains that mountain ranges are created where two continental plates come together at a convergent plate boundary.
Discusses the differences between active and passive continental margins are their relationships with plate tectonic activity.
Descibes the supercontinent cycle and its relationship to past and future plate tetonic activity.
Describes how volcanic activity can take place within an oceanic or continental lithospheric plate above a hotspot.
Defines types of stress in rocks and the possible strain effects.
Discusses a basic principle in geology in which sedimentary rocks are laid down horizontally from oldest at the bottom to youngest at the top.
Presents types of folds including monoclines, anticlines, and synclines.
Designates types of faults based on the movement of the two blocks of crust including reverse, normal, thrust, and strike-slip.
Describes how mountain ranges are built by continent-continent convergence, subduction of an oceanic plate, and continental rifting.
Illuminates the causes of earthquakes by elastic rebound theory and earthquake location as focus and epicenter.
Reviews the locations of earthquakes at plate boundaries, and the numbers of quakes of different sizes.
Discusses the large, shallow focus earthquakes at transform plate boundaries with particular emphasis on the San Andreas Fault Zone.
Describes how massive earthquakes occur at convergent plate boundaries.
Discusses how intraplate earthquakes are the result of a solid slab of crust moving on a round Earth and the reactivation of faults.
The seismic waves that emanate from earthquakes include body waves and surface waves.
Discusses tsunamis which are also known as seismic sea waves - a series of enormous waves created by underwater disturbances such as earthquakes, landslides, volcanic eruptions, or meteorites.
Looks at two recent devastating tsunami: the Indian Ocean in 2004 and Japan in 2011.
Covers the instruments scientists use to measure earthquake magnitude and learn about Earth's interior.
Explains how to find an earthquake epicenter using at least three seismograph stations.
Describes the scales scientists use to indicate the intensity and magnitude of an earthquake including the Mercalli, Richter, and moment magnitude.
Introduces the signs that scientist see prior to an earthquake occuring.
Identifies the factors that contribute to the damage caused to a region by an earthquake, including ground type and size.
Reveals how buildings can be made to withstand earthquakes and how pipes can be designed to reduce fire hazard after an earthquake.
Describes how individuals can prepare for an earthquake and stay safe in and after an earthquake.
Looks at where volcanoes are found, where magma arises, and if they are active, dormant, or extinct.
Volcanoes are found at convergent plate boundaries due to melting resulting from subduction, and at divergent plate boundaries due to pressure release.
Elucidates hotspot activity and how it leads to volcanism in the oceans.
Reveals that the amount of silica in a magma determines if it erupts explosively or effusively.
Explains that felsic magmas erupt explosively, causing widespread damage.
Mafic magmas erupt effusively causing large lava flows that are easy to get away from.
Discusses the signs that scientists use to predict volcanic eruptions.
Describes the types of volcanoes produced by different magma types.
Supervolcano eruptions are rare, but unimaginably large.
Describes the landforms created by different types of magma, including domes by felsic magmas and lava plateaus by mafic lavas.
Water that is heated by hot rock or magma flows to the surface as a hot spring or erupts as a geyser.
Delineates weathering, the breakdown of solid rock into smaller pieces, from erosion, the transport of those pieces to another location, both of which modify landscapes.
Describes mechanical weathering as the breakdown of rocks and minerals without changing their chemical composition.
Describes chemical weathering as the breakdown of rocks and minerals by changing their chemical composition by water, carbon dioxide, oxygen, and other compounds.
Identifies and explains factors that lead to differences in the rate and intensity of weathering.
Reveals the characteristics of soils that result from the proportion of silt, clay, and sand, and the interactions with air, water, and living things.
Discusses the factors that affect soil formation like climate, rock type, slope, time, and biological activity.
Describes the characteristics of different layers of soil including topsoil, subsoil, and the C-horizon.
Defines different types of soils including pedalfer, pedocal, and laterite.
Streams erode sediments and create landscape features, like meanders.
Rivers erode, carry, and deposit sediments.

Level 3: Landforms from Stream Erosion and Deposition
Description: Elucidates how and where rivers erode and deposit sediments, including particles and dissolved ions.
Groundwater erodes rock, especially carbonate rock, to create caves.
Groundwater creates features like caves and their interior formations, such as stalactites and stalagmites.

Level 3: Landforms from Groundwater Erosion and Deposition
Description: Reveals how groundwater creates features like caves and their interior formations.
Wave erosion creates landforms like sea cliffs.
Waves deposit sediments to create coastal features like barrier islands and spits.

Level 3: Landforms from Wave Erosion and Deposition
Description: Distinguishes between erosional and depositional features created by waves on a shoreline.
Humans attempt to protect shorelines from erosion by constructing breakwaters, groins, and seawalls.
Wind erodes sediments to form terrain features, especially in the desert.
Wind transports and deposits sediments to create features like sand dunes and loess deposits.

Level 3: Landforms from Wind Erosion and Deposition
Description: Explains wind erosion and deposition, where ventifacts and sand dunes are created.
Features created by glacial erosion may be massive, like hanging valleys and horns, or smaller, like glacial striations.
Features created by glacial deposition include glacial tills and moraines.

Level 3: Landforms from Glacial Erosion and Deposition
Description: Describes the mostly massive features created by glacial erosion and deposition.

Level 3: Landforms from Erosion and Deposition by Gravity
Description: Indicates the factors that lead to landslides and other mass movements, what their characteristics are, and how to avoid them.
Defines different types of fossils, including body and trace fossils, and what characteristics in an organism most likely lead to fossilization.
Describes five processes that create fossils.

Level 3: Earth History and Clues from Fossils
Description: Explains how scientists can use fossils to reveal details about Earth history.
Introduces Steno's laws, which allow scientists to decipher the geological events that occurred and the order in which they took place.
Distinguishes how to tell which rock unit is older than the ones around it and so reveal the geologic history of the region.
Describes how a single rock unit can be used as the basis of piecing together a geologic history for the region.
Discusses how major events in the evolution of life are divided into units and used by scientists to divide up the geologic time scale to refer to times in Earth history.

Level 3: Tree Rings, Ice Cores, and Varves
Description: Introduces three methods scientists use to determine the absolute age of a material: tree rings, ice cores, and varves.

Level 3: Radioactive Decay as a Measure of Age
Description: Explains radioactive decay, including parent and daughter isotopes, and half lives, and its importance.
Elaborates on radioactive decay as a tool for determining the age of certain minerals and other materials, including the limits of the technique.
Presents some of the ways scientists have tried to determine Earth's age over time, and how we now know that Earth is about 4.6 billion years old.

Level 3: Formation of the Sun and Planets
Description: Describes the nebular hypothesis for the formation of the sun and planets of our solar system and the scientific evidence for the hypothesis.
Discusses how Earth formed and evolved during its early days, and the evidence scientists have for this.
Presents the hypothesis for how our Moon formed.
Describes the evolution of Earth's atmosphere from volcanic outgassing and comet impacts through the evolution of photosynthesis.
Discusses how the early continents formed and where we can see evidence of them in cratons today.
Traces plate tectonics from early in Earth's history through the formation of supercontinents about 1.1 billion years ago.
Describes how the continents came together in a giant landmass known as Pangaea around 250 million years ago and how mountain ranges were created from these collisions.
Reveals that during the Paleozoic and Mesozoic, six marine transgressions and regressions caused sea level to rise over the continents, leaving evidence in rocks in the Grand Canyon and elsewhere.
Describes why and how a supercontinent would break apart, by continental rifting that caused the breakup of Pangaea along with the formation of the Atlantic Ocean.
Traces the geology of the Cenozoic from the drifting apart of the Pangaean continents, the subduction of the Farallon plate, and the Pleistocene Ice Age.
Reviews the distribution of water on Earth: 97% in oceans and most of the fresh water frozen into ice.
Water is a polar molecule and the only substance that can be any of the three states of matter on Earth.
Describes how the three processes of water, evaporation, precipitation, and sublimination, carry water between reservoirs.
Defines the features of streams including headwater, base level, and tributary.
Distinguishes between ponds and lakes, their characteristics, and zonation.
Describes the causes of floods, their effects, how humans prevent them, and the consequences of preventing them.
Reveals the characteristics of continental and alpine glaciers including their formation, movement, and features.
Explains the location of groundwater and where most of the water in aquifers today came from.
An aquifer is made of porous rock between impermeable layers; the water table rises and falls.
Hot water can flow to the surface at a hot spring or erupt as a geyser.
Learn about how important the oceans are to the water cycle, climate, and biodiversity.
Reveals the composition of seawater and the sources of the materials, especially the salts.
Identifies and describes vertical and horizontal zones in the ocean.
Describes the characteristics of different layers of soil including topsoil, subsoil, and the C-horizon.
Reveals tidal patterns and that tides are caused by the gravitational attraction of the Sun and Moon to Earth.
Describes how surface ocean currents are the result of the global wind patterns and Coriolis effect
Reveals how ocean currents transfer heat around the globe using the Gulf Stream as an example.
Learn how water with different densities drive deep ocean circulation.
Introduces some of the organisms living in the sea, such as tiny plankton, submerged fish, and shorebirds.
Food energy in the marine environment comes from photosynthesis at the surface or chemosynthesis at hydrothermal vents.
Describes some ocean ecosystem including those two different energy sources: photosynthesizing phytoplankton and chemosynthetic bacteria.
Reviews some of the functions of the atmosphere including as part of the water cycle, moderating global temperature and protecting the surface from harmful solar radiation.
Outlines the composition of the atmosphere with the major gases nitrogen and oxygen and the minor gases like carbon dioxide that are greenhouse gases.
Looks at the relationships between altitude, air pressure, density, and their causes.
Learn that different layers of the atmosphere are separated by their different temperature gradients, and that warm air rises and cool air sinks.
Describes the troposphere, the layer of the atmosphere closest to the surface.
The stratosphere contains the ozone layer, which protects life on Earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation.
Delineates the mesosphere as the layer above the stratosphere with a very low density of gas molecules.
Defines the outer atmosphere, including the thermosphere and exosphere, as having magnetic field lines that protect Earth from the solar wind.
Identifies and defines types of electromagnetic radiation.
Explains that temperature is the speed of vibration of molecules in a substance and heat is the energy transferred between substances.
Describes the radiation Earth receives from the Sun from ultraviolet to infrared.
Explains how in the atmosphere, heat is transferred by radiation, conduction, and convection.
Reveals what happens to the solar energy that enters Earth's atmosphere and how that affects the heat budget.
Earth receives different amounts of solar energy at different latitudes, with the most at the equator and the least at the poles.
Describes how greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide, methane, and water vapor, trap heat in the atmosphere, and that levels of these gases are increasing due to human activities.
Illustrates the six convection cells in the atmosphere, three in each hemisphere.
Reveals how differences in solar radiation create the global wind belts, and how global winds influence climate.
Describes local winds as occurring between high and low pressure regions, including land, sea, and mountain breezes.
Weather is a short-term phenomenon that primarily considers temperature, precipitation, with winds.
Compares and contrasts the short-term phenomenon of weather with the long-term average of weather, otherwise known as climate.
The amount of water vapor in air is its humidity; the water condenses when the temperature reaches its dew point.
Describes how clouds form and explains how different cloud types may reveal a change in weather.
Fog is like a cloud on the ground; water vapor condenses to form a mist.
Elucidates the various types of precipitation and how convection in a cloud can cause raindrops to grow.
Describes that air masses have the same temperature and humidity, and what happens when air masses move.
Reveals the fronts that arise when two or three air masses collide.
Explains how thunderstorms arise, grow by convection, produce lightning and thunder, and may appear in a squall line.
Describes what tornadoes are, how they form, and the scale on which they are measured.
States that cyclones are systems of rotating winds, and how and where mid-latitude cyclones form.
Distinguishes hurricanes as tropical cyclones that form in warm water and can do tremendous amounts of damage.
Presents blizzards as storms that form when cold, dry air contacts warm, moist air, or a lake allowing lots of precipitation to fall as snow.
Describes heat waves and droughts as phenomena that are more extreme versions of normal weather.
Introduces the instruments scientists use to measure weather conditions, including advanced tools like satellites and radar.
Elucidates the work of meteorologists who predict weather using data entered into mathematical models run on computers.
Describes how meteorologists use weather maps to illustrate temperature, pressure, and other weather phenomena.
Describes how latitude determines the amount of solar radiation a region will receive and how that will affect the temperature and climate.
Explains how the atmospheric circulation cells and the high and low pressure zones between them help to determine a region's climate.
Defines marine and continental climates and how the position of a location on a continent relative to the ocean affects its climate.
Studies the effects of altitude and mountain ranges on weather and climate.
Describes how biomes are regions with similar climate and, as a result, with similar organisms.
Warm and wet tropical climates are found near the equator; they are home to tropical rainforests.
Dry climates are found in high pressure zones; they produce deserts and steppes.
Temperate climates have moderate temperatures and differ in the amount of rain they get.
Continental climates have large swings in temperature because they are away from the ocean's moderation of climate.
Polar climates are found near the polar regions; they include permafrost and tundra.
Identifies the component parts and types of biological communities, including living and nonliving factors.
Describes the different roles in an ecosystem by what an organism eats and its relationship to other organisms.
Reveals that energy is transferred between organisms in one direction in a food chain, but that interconnected food chains make a food web.
Describes that matter circulates through ecosystems in many directions.
Nitrogen is essential to living things but to be useful to organisms it must be fixed by bacteria.
Describes freshwater ecosystems, including wetlands, which perform extremely important ecosystem services.
Briefly pictures modern biodiversity, which results from the evolution of billions of organisms into a tremendous variety of habitats.
Explains how natural selection favors certain traits in a population so that the organism adapts to its environment and that changes in the genes over time is evolution.

Level 3: Theory of Evolution by Natural Selection
Description: Natural selection favors certain traits in a population so that the organism adapts to its environment; changes in the genes over time is evolution.
Describes how limiting factors determine the carrying capacity for a population in an environment.
Reveals that after a mass extinction evolution works rapidly to create new species that can fill the vacant habitats.
Discusses the characteristics of living organisms and how life may have originated.
Chemical reactions make an organism's metabolism, and nucleic acids pass genetic information to the next generation.
Discusses the characteristics of living organisms and how life may have originated.

Level 3: Evolution of Eukaryotes to Multicellular Life
Description: Describes how chemical reactions make an organism metabolism, and nucleic acids pass genetic information to the next generation.

Level 2: History of Earth's Complex Life Forms

Description: Life has come a long way in the Phanerozoic beginning with the Cambrian explosion and going through multiple extinctions and radiations.
Reveals the patterns of biological evolution during the Paleozoic, from the Cambrian explosion to the largest extinction of all time at the end of the Permian.
Describes the diversification of life during the Mesozoic, including the dinosaurs, and the mass extinction that came from a giant asteroid impact.
Reveals the radiation of life into niches left vacant by the Cretaceous extinction, as well as the evolution and extinction of the Pleistocene megafauna.
Identifies and describes very briefly the evolution of large-brained, bipedal humans from a common ancestor with apes.

Level 3: Life and the Geologic Time Scale
Description: Major events in the evolution of life are used to divide up the geologic time scale.

Level 1: Human Impacts on the Earth's Environment

Description: Explains the more than exponential growth of human populations and predicts what the population might be at the end of this century.
Reveals how human population growth has paralleled advances in agriculture, such as the advent of agriculture, and the onset of the Green Revolution.
Human population growth has paralleled advances in agriculture, such as the advent of agriculture, and the onset of the Green Revolution.
Describes the consequences of the Green Revolution, and how overconsumption impacts Earth systems.
The Green Revolution allowed populations to grow extremely large; growth in the future may depend on new advances.
Describes sustainable development, its goals, and how humans might become more conscious of ways to meet those goals.
Explains soil erosion and the processes that cause exacerbate it, including human activities.
Describes the importance of soil as a renewable resource and techniques for lessening soil erosion.
Describes hazardous waste as materials that are toxic, chemically active, corrosive or flammable, and how these materials impact\ the environment.
Discusses the impacts of hazardous waste on the environment and human health, and the provisions of the Superfund Act.
Explains how to prevent hazardous waste pollution and how the Superfund Act regulates this type of pollution.
Describes types of mining, their environmental costs, and reclamation.
Describes the ways in which humans use water.
Explains the distribution of water around the world and the causes and consequences of water scarcity.
Reveals the hazards of waterborne illnesses that infect more than 1 billion people who do not have access to safe water.
Describes the sources of water pollution, such as municipal, industrial, and agricultural.
Explains why keeping water from being polluted is preferable to cleaning it after being polluted, and what has happened since the passage of the Clean Water Act in the U.S.
Discusses what happens when groundwater is pumped from an aquifer, including some of the negative consequences.
Describes how pollution enters and spreads within a groundwater aquifer.
Explains the steps needed to clean a groundwater aquifer.
Encourages people to conserve water collectively and individually.
Explains how dead zones form in coastal regions where excess fertilizer causes rampant algal growth.
Discusses how trash ends up in the ocean and the ways that plastic trash can harm marine organisms, even if it breaks down.
Describes the damage that occurs from oil spills, and what can be done to clean them up.
Presents information on the compounds that pollute the air, their sources, and the regions in which air quality is chronically bad.
Distinguishes between primary and secondary pollutants and identifies examples of each.
Describes the pollutants released from fossil fuels, biomass burning, and volatile organic compounds.

Level 3: Effects of Air Pollution on the Environment
Description: Explores how air pollutants harm the environment by reducing photosynthesis, changing temperature and precipitation, and causing acid rain.

Level 3: Effects of Air Pollution on Human Health
Description: Describes the human health consequences of air pollution such as asthma and lung cancer.
Explains how mercury enters the environment, alters to a toxic form, and poses a threat to human health.
Acid rain is caused by sulfur and nitrous oxides mixing with water in the atmosphere and can cause tremendous consequences in the environment.
Describes how the ozone hole forms and the effects on the environment and life beneath it.
Explores some of the technologies that reduce air pollution, and some types of clean energy that can be developed.
Describes how ozone depletion was discovered and how governments worldwide work together to regulate the production and consumption of ozone-destroying chemicals.
Traces changes in Earth's climate through Earth history, especially in the past 2,000 years.
Discusses how El Nio and La Nia form and how various regions on Earth are affected by those changes in the atmosphere and oceans.
Explains mechanisms that have long-term impacts on climate, like Milankovitch cycles and changes in atmospheric greenhouse gases.
Explains the cycle of carbon through the atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.
Reveals that the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere correlates with the rise in global temperatures.

Level 3: Causes and Effects of Global Warming
Description: Warmer global temperatures are the result of increased greenhouse gases in the troposphere; there are many possible consequences of global warming.
Describes the likely impacts of continued global warming, such as increases in ocean acidity and changes in snow packs.
Explores some of the methods for lessening greenhouse gas pollution that have been proposed, including cap-and-trade, carbon taxes, and geoengineering.
Our Sun is a star undergoing nuclear fusion in its core.
Identifies the internal layers of the Sun, which are made of plasa, including where nuclear fusion takes place.
Describes how heat moves through the outer layers of the Sun.
Describes the surface features of the Sun, including sunspots, solar prominences, solar flares, and coronal mass ejections.
Covers the history of astronomy from the ancient Greeks through the Big Bang.
Reviews the planets of the solar system with increasing distance from the sun, their orbits, and rotations.

Level 3: Planet Orbits in the Solar System
Description: Describes the size and shapes of the orbits of the eight planets.
Defines Newton's Universal Law of Gravitation that all objects have a gravitational attraction proportional to their mass and distance from each other.
Compares and contrasts the characteristics of the inner and outer planets.
Describes Mercury, the closest planet to the Sun.
Describes Venus, with its active volcanoes and runaway greenhouse effect.
Identifies the characteristics of the Moon, including the internal structure and surface rock types.
Mars, the planet we know best, has interesting surface features including evidence for running water.
Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a storm that has been active for more than 300 years; its moon Europa has liquid water.
Describes Saturn, its beautiful rings, and its moon Titan, which may have liquid water.
Describes Uranus, the tilted ringed, blue outer planet.
Describes Neptune, the farthest planet from the Sun, its reverse orbit, and blue color.
Covers the methods scientists use to locate, study, and describe exoplanets, which are planets outside of our solar system that orbit a star.
Explains the locations and characteristics of asteroids, including ones that someday may strike Earth.
Describes comets, their composition, where they originate, and what happens to them.
Defines meteors, meteoroids, and meteorites and summarizes their properties.
Identifies and describes the dwarf planets, including Pluto, and why they are not planets.
Reviews the constellations and explains how distance works in space.
Examines the role of nuclear fusion in the life cycle of stars, and what particle accelerators reveal.
Identifies how stars are classified by color and temperature.
Summarizes the life cycles of different types of stars.
Stars are formed from a nebula, and have different life cycles depending on their size.
Stars spend much of their lives on the main sequence, which classifies stars that are fusing hydrogen into helium.
Stars may become a red giant or a white dwarfs, depending on its size.
Supernova explosions fuse the heavier elements and blow them around that part of space.
Neutron stars and black holes evolve from old, dense stars.
Explains that parallax is used to measure distances to objects a few hundred light years from Earth, but brightness is used for objects at greater distances.
Star clusters can be open clusters or globular clusters.
